Award.AwardTitle: Travel Grants for US Participants in the Mathematical Congress of the Americas, Buenos Aires, Argentina, July 19 - 24, 2021
Award.AbstractNarration:
To support participation in the Mathematical Congress of the Americas (MCA), to be held July 19 – 24, 2021 in Buenos Aires, Argentina, the American Mathematical Society (AMS) will administer a travel-grant program for mathematicians based in the United States (US)—those who are students or faculty in US institutions or employees of US organizations or companies. The Society will strive to draw a robust and diverse applicant pool by utilizing its infrastructure of communications and its connectivity in the mathematical community, and it will work to ensure that mathematicians from groups historically underrepresented in STEM areas receive particular attention. In the selection process, AMS expects to give priority to early-career applicants. MCA is a quadrennial gathering, initiated in 2013, with the goal "to internationally highlight the excellence of mathematical achievements in the Americas and foster collaborations among researchers, students, institutions, and mathematical societies in the Americas." The conference is administered by the Mathematical Council of the Americas, a network of over twenty societies, institutes, and agencies throughout North America, South America, Central America, and the Caribbean nations. This third Congress will draw top-tier mathematicians from around the Western Hemisphere and the rest of the world. It will provide an excellent opportunity for exchange of ideas in a broad array of mathematical areas and for the US to be well represented in the international arena. The US sustains its highly-regarded research endeavor, in part, by fostering the participation of its citizens in international conferences. MCA presents an excellent opportunity for such participation, both by established researchers as well as those who will become the research leaders of the future. Those traveling to Buenos Aires will be able to share in person the results of their research and garner new ideas from their counterparts from across the Americas, thereby enriching the hemispheric and worldwide endeavor of mathematical discovery.


The organizers of MCA 2021 anticipate approximately one thousand attendees from around the Western Hemisphere and the rest of the world. The six plenary speakers are Ian Agol (University of California, Berkeley, USA), Julia Chuzhoy (Toyota Technological Institute at Chicago, USA), Carlos Kenig (University of Chicago, USA), Allan Sly (Princeton University, USA), Claire Voisin (Collège de France, France), and Miguel Walsh (Universidad de Buenos Aires, Argentina). Twenty-two Invited Speakers represent such topical areas as algebraic geometry, analysis, probability, ergodic theory, differential geometry, partial differential equations, relativity and gravitation, numerical analysis, graph theory and combinatorics, applied computational analysis, complex analytic geometry, dynamical systems, Riemann manifolds, algebraic topology, geometry, stochastic calculus, fractal geometry, number theory, model theory, statistical mechanics, and neuroscience. The conference will include a wide array of special session topics, and it is anticipated that the schedule will include multiple panel and poster sessions as well as social and cultural events. The MCA is also the occasion for awarding the MCA Prize, the Americas Prize, and the Solomon Lefschetz Medals. The Congress presents a splendid opportunity for early-career mathematicians to share their knowledge, garner new ideas, and interact with counterparts and luminaries on the international stage. Current information about MCA 2021 is at www.mca2021.org, and the AMS travel grant program is detailed at https://www.ams.org/programs/travel-grants/mca.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the Travel Grants for US Participants in the Mathematical Congress of the Americas, Buenos Aires, Argentina, July 19 - 24, 2021 award (Federal Award ID 2015529) was to support participation by US-based mathematicians in the quadrennial Mathematical Congress of the Americas (MCA), July 19 - 23, 2021, in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Emphasis was placed on providing early-career mathematicians opportunities to present research, learn of research that is international in scope and spanning a spectrum of mathematical areas, and encounter researchers from outside the US.

Prompted by ongoing pandemic conditions, with approval of the NSF program officer, this award was used to support attendance of the online Mathematical Congress of the Americas (MCA) in summer 2021 and the online Joint Mathematics Meetings (JMM) in April 2022. With approval of the NSF program officer, the AMS used the remaining funding from this award to augment the Graduate Student Travel Grant Program for JMM 2023 in Boston, MA, the first in-person JMM meeting since 2020. No additional funds from this award have been used since the AMS's 2023 report on this grant.

In October 2020, the MCA organizing committee announced that the event would move from its intended venue in Buenos Aires, to an online platform. The dates and scientific program remained unchanged. With the approval of the NSF program officer, the AMS offered "virtual travel grants" that paid awardees' MCA registration fee and provided a stipend of up to $250 to help the awardees participate as fully as possible MCA activities. The AMS received 165 applications for these grants. Staff determined eligibility, 155 applicants were offered grants, and 140 accepted. After the MCA, AMS staff issued a brief survey to awardees, processed vouchers, and completed payments. Based on narrative responses to the AMS's survey of recipients, many awardees took advantage of the online functionality to establish or renew connections among MCA participants. Awardees were specific about the special sessions that proved valuable, new people encountered and the resulting opportunities for future interactions, and new mathematical ideas inspired by the talks.

The AMS intended to use the remaining funds from this award to support US-based graduate students' travel to JMM 2022 in Seattle, WA. The AMS received 226 applications for JMM 2022 travel grants, and 172 awards of up to $1,300 ($800 from the MCA grant and $500 from an AMS donor) were made, with 163 accepting. When JMM 2022 shifted to an online event, with the approval of the NSF program officer, the AMS modified the support in these grants to cover only the $40 graduate student JMM registration fee for the original awardees, and approximately 103 of these individuals used the funding to attend the online JMM in April 2022.

Graduate Student Travel Grant funding to attend JMM 2023 in Boston, MA, came from the remainder of funds left in this award plus support from the AMS Next Generation Fund. The AMS received 195 applications; 154 awards of up to $1,300 were offered; and 142 students accepted the award, completed travel, and were issued travel support. Selection criteria prioritized awarding funds to those students who were within 2 years of PhD completion, were presenting research at the JMM, and indicated this award would be instrumental to their ability to attend the JMM. As this was the first in-person JMM since 2020, students were especially appreciative of the opportunity to share research, build their networks, and explore job opportunities with more than 5,000 other mathematicians.
